body:
Fix for https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31954

The code works but I don't know how to write tests for it, so I have marked the PR as a draft for now.

comment_data.body: Hi, I just stumbled upon this MR and I'm wondering, is this `print` intentional or just a forgotten debug print?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -113,11 +121,26 @@ function M.range(bufnr, ns, higroup, start, finish, opts)
       strict = false,
     })
   end
+
+  if timeout ~= -1 then
+    print(timeout)

comment_data.body: Oh no! That was left by mistake. Fixed it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -113,11 +121,26 @@ function M.range(bufnr, ns, higroup, start, finish, opts)
       strict = false,
     })
   end
+
+  if timeout ~= -1 then
+    print(timeout)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  if range_timer and not range_timer:closing() then
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -100,6 +107,19 @@ function M.range(bufnr, ns, higroup, start, finish, opts)
     end
   end
 
+  if range_timer then

comment_data.body: I have made the change but I'm curious, what exactly does `is_closing()` do? The documentation just states that it returns `true` if the timer is closing, but how does that help? Does running `close` on an already closing timer cause some error?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -100,6 +107,19 @@ function M.range(bufnr, ns, higroup, start, finish, opts)
     end
   end
 
+  if range_timer then

@@ -156,27 +178,14 @@ function M.on_yank(opts)
 
   local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
   local winid = vim.api.nvim_get_current_win()
-  if yank_timer then
-    yank_timer:close()
-    assert(yank_cancel)
-    yank_cancel()
-  end
 
   vim.api.nvim__ns_set(yank_ns, { wins = { winid } })
   M.range(bufnr, yank_ns, higroup, "'[", "']", {
     regtype = event.regtype,
     inclusive = event.inclusive,
     priority = opts.priority or M.priorities.user,
+    timeout = timeout,

@@ -31,6 +33,10 @@ M.priorities = {
 --- Highlight priority
 --- (default: `vim.hl.priorities.user`)
 --- @field priority? integer
+---
+--- Time in ms before highlight is cleared
+--- (default: -1 (inactive))

comment_data.body: aha typo it's `is_closing` safely check timer is not closing ..
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -100,6 +107,19 @@ function M.range(bufnr, ns, higroup, start, finish, opts)
     end
   end
 
+  if range_timer then

comment_data.body: add a blank line above this.

"correctly" is never needed in test names. tests are assumed to assert correctness.

```suggestion
  it('removes highlight after given `timeout`', function ()
```

comment_regular_data.body: You should refactor the `hl.on_yank()` function to use the new option rather than set its own timer.

Needs a test in `test/functional/lua/hl_spec.lua`. You can [run the test](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/test/README.md#filter-by-file) like this:

    TEST_FILE=test/functional/lua/hl_spec.lua make functionaltest

For testing timer-based behavior, note that:

- `screen:expect()` has very good handling of timing.
- `t.retry()` is also available to retry assertions that are waiting for something.

For the test, I have written this:

```lua
  it('correctly removes highlight after timeout time', function ()
    local timeout = 1000
    exec_lua(function ()
      local ns = vim.api.nvim_create_namespace('')
      vim.hl.range(0, ns, 'Search', { 0, 0 }, { 4, 0 }, { timeout = timeout })
    end)
    screen:expect([[
      {10:^asdfghjkl}{100:$}                                                  |
      {10:«口=口»}{100:$}                                                    |
      {10:qwertyuiop}{100:$}                                                 |
      {10:口口=口口}{1:$}                                                  |
      zxcvbnm{1:$}                                                    |
                                                                  |
    ]])
    vim.uv.sleep(timeout)
    screen:expect([[
      ^asdfghjkl{1:$}                                                  |
      «口=口»{1:$}                                                    |
      qwertyuiop{1:$}                                                 |
      口口=口口{1:$}                                                  |
      zxcvbnm{1:$}                                                    |
                                                                  |
    ]])
  end)
```

The `screen:expect` calls have been filled in using `screen:snapshot_util()`. I'm not sure if using `vim.uv.sleep` is the best way to check if the timeout works but I couldn't think of any other way. `screen:expect` has a timeout option, but setting `{ timeout = timeout }` after the string doesn't seem to work.

> I'm not sure if using `vim.uv.sleep` is the best way to check if the timeout works but I couldn't think of any other way.

`screen:expect` will wait for the expected screen state. sleep() shouldn't be needed

Seems like I misunderstood the function of `screen:expect`

So do I put just one `screen:expect` call for the final state, or two: one for the initial highlight and then one after that to check that the highlight is cleared?

Two would be better, right?

> two: one for the initial highlight and then one after that to check that the highlight is cleared?

that's the usual recommended way.
